ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Nonorganic hearing loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Inconsistent behavioral thresholds, significant SRT/PTA mismatch, positive Stenger test, robust DPOAEs despite behavioral 'loss', and physiologically impossible unmasked bone conduction thresholds.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Sudden Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SSNHL)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Suggested by initial history and outside audiogram showing severe mixed loss, but ruled out by subsequent objective testing and inconsistencies.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Initial assessment of hearing sensitivity at outside clinic.
Assessment of speech reception and recognition at outside clinic.
Assessment of middle ear function at outside clinic.
Follow-up evaluation to monitor hearing post-treatment.
Follow-up evaluation to check agreement with pure-tone thresholds.
To evaluate for nonorganic hearing loss given asymmetry.
Objective assessment of cochlear outer hair cell function to cross-check behavioral results.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial evaluation at an outside clinic demonstrated a mild flat SNHL in the right ear and a severe mixed hearing loss in the left ear. SRTs were consistent with PTAs bilaterally, and tympanometry was normal. The findings were initially interpreted as SSNHL.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: mild flat SNHL (PTA ~30 dB HL). Left ear: severe mixed flat loss (PTA ~80 dB HL).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT Right: 30 dB HL, Left: 80 dB HL. WRS Right: 100%, Left: 72%.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Normal middle ear pressure, volume, and compliance bilaterally (Type A).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Follow-up evaluation revealed significant inconsistencies suggestive of nonorganic hearing loss. Reliability was poor. Re-instruction improved AC thresholds but created a significant SRT/PTA mismatch. A positive Stenger test was obtained. Objective DPOAEs were robust, and unmasked BC thresholds showed a lack of cross-hearing that is physiologically impossible.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Initial Left PTA 68 dB HL. Post-reinstruction Left PTA 51 dB HL. Unmasked BC left significantly poorer than right, violating interaural attenuation principles.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Initial Left SRT 75 dB HL. Repeat Left SRT 40 dB HL. Significant mismatch with PTA (11 dB difference). WRS Left 88%.

tests.name: Stenger Test
tests.result_summary: Positive pure-tone Stenger at 250 to 8,000 Hz.

tests.name: Otoacoustic Emissions (DPOAE)
tests.result_summary: Present and robust at 1,600 to 6,300 Hz bilaterally, consistent with normal cochlear function in speech frequencies.

proposed_items: Follow-up with otolaryngology to discuss audiologic findings.
counseling_actions: Explain that objective tests (DPOAEs) indicate the inner ear is functioning normally.
Discuss inconsistencies observed in behavioral testing (e.g., due to strain or fatigue).
Reassure the patient that hearing sensitivity appears better than behavioral tests suggest.
Counsel that steroids might not improve hearing (done previously).

escalation.rationale_short: To review findings of nonorganic hearing loss and prevent further unnecessary medical intervention.

follow_up_plan.objective: Review comprehensive audiologic findings with the otolaryngologist.

expected_outcome: Patient cancelled the follow-up appointment with otolaryngology and did not reschedule.
Authors speculate the patient became aware that the audiologist suspected malingering.
